preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: These Tagging Guidelines describe Nature's preferred XML tagging style for journal article submissions in the NLM Journal Publishing DTD v3.0. All deliveries made to Nature must conform to the provisions of this document.

The Tagging Guidelines are divided into separate chapters. Each chapter describes separate rules that must be followed when creating Nature-style compliant XML. Many of the rules are related, but none are duplicated from one chapter to another.

listitem.para: General tagging practice: These style rules apply to structured data tagging at a very broad level and include emphasised text, mathematics, and special characters.
Document objects: This chapter describes specific parts of XML documents like figures and author/affiliation relationships. It references specific elements and includes examples of XML tagging.

Elements: This chapter describes style rules for specific XML elements and their attributes. Only elements for which Nature has a style rule are described in this section. Refer to the NLM Tag Library for descriptions of all elements available in the DTD.
Journal-specific information: This chapter gives journal-id and copyright statements for specific Nature journals.

preface.para: In addition to these chapters, all updates to the Tagging Guidelines will be documented in the [Update History].[* Insert link to this document once created *]

simplesect.title: A note on presentation
simplesect.para: Elements are shown within angled brackets. Attributes are preceeded by the @ sign. Both are shown in a monospace font to distinguish them from regular text.

simplesect.title: Packaging format
simplesect.para: XML files should be uploaded by the Nature NLM web validation service. Associated files (images, pdfs etc) should continue to be submitted using the current method. This is likely to change in the future with all files submitted through the web service.

simplesect.title: Media files
simplesect.para: [*Add requirements once we want all content through the web service*]

simplesect.title: Fully-tagged samples
simplesect.para: Fully-tagged articles are available for download. [*Add links to our samples and/or create new ones - perhaps have a download page with DTD and Schematron rules as well*]

chapter.title: General tagging practice
chapter.para: The XML should conform to the NLM Journal Publishing DTD, version 3.0 incorporating the Oasis table model. (http://dtd.nlm.nih.gov/publishing/3.0/index.html) [* Change link to our OASIS enabled version of the DTD (downloads page?) *]
The complete NLM Tag Library is available on the web: http://dtd.nlm.nih.gov/publishing/tag-library/3.0/index.html

section.title: Emphasised text
section.para: As a rule, use emphasised text markup (, , , etc) only to set off a piece of information. Do not set entire elements in emphasised text. For example, if a is set completely in boldface, do not tag the <bold>. However, if a title has a word or some words set in boldface for emphasis, tag those words using <bold>. Mainly this will apply to <title>, <p> in <abstract>, and <label>. It might also show up in <aff> and "special" sections, like <ack>.

In addition, it may sometimes be necessary to reverse presentational formats. For example (from Scientific American): Gareth Cook is a Pulitzer Prize–winning journalist at the Boston Globe and editor of the Scientific American Mind neuroscience blog Mind Matters.
section.programlisting: <aff><bold>Gareth Cook</bold> is a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist at the <italic>Boston Globe</italic> and editor of the <italic>Scientific American Mind</italic> neuroscience blog Mind Matters.</aff>

section.title: Empty elements
section.para: Do not use empty elements for the purpose of formatting.
All required elements should have content.

section.title: Links
section.para: Tag all links within the document (e.g. tables, figures, display formula) with the <xref> element and include the appropriate @ref-type. See <xref>.
Tag all external links with <ext-link> and include the appropriate @ext-link-type. See <ext-link>.

Tag all links to related articles (e.g. from a correction to the corrected article) with <related-article> and include the appropriate @ext-link-type, @related-article-type, and citation information. See <related-article>.

section.title: Mathematics
section.para: [*Placeholder for information on required use of MathML.*]

section.title: Use of Unicode
section.para: Do not use named character entities within NLM markup, apart from the predefined XML entities (< for <, > for >, and & for &).
Tag non-ASCII characters with their Unicode hex number in character entity style (e.g. × for ×).

Do not use values from the Private Use Areas: xE000–xF8FF, xF0000–xFFFFD, and x100000–x10FFFD. Do not use Unicode values designated as control codes. These ranges include but are not limited to x0000–0020, x0080–x009F.
[*Info from Jude on "unsafe" entities which will require Stix fonts*]

chapter.title: Document objects
chapter.para: These Document Objects refer to pieces of the XML documents that define a single concept (author/affiliation relationships, copyright information) and often include several XML elements in their tagging.

sect1.title: Abstracts
sect1.para: Articles may contain multiple abstracts and summaries. Specify @abstract-type for summaries which are not a true abstract. See <abstract> for examples.

sect1.title: Accession groups
sect1.para: Accession codes for linking to entries in Genbank and Brookhaven National Laboratory and Protein Data Bank should be set in <back><notes> with @notes-type="database-links".
Example:
sect1.programlisting:
ATP2A1

U96781

1JTG

AF482946

sect1.title: Article categories
sect1.para: Articles may have more than one subject group within <article-categories>, but every article must have exactly one <subj-group> with @subj-group-type="category". This value should match the value for the required @article-type on the root <article> element.

Articles may also have sub-categories and sub-sub-categories for second and third level article types. These should also be set as <subj-group> with @subj-group-type="sub-category" or @subj-group-type="sub-sub-category".
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <article-categories> <subj-group subj-group-type="category"> <subject>naturejobs</subject> </subj-group> <subj-group subj-group-type="sub-category"> <subject>carv</subject> </subj-group> <subj-group subj-group-type="sub-sub-category"> <subject>grad</subject> </subj-group> </article-categories>
sect1.para: See also <article-categories>.

sect2.title: Magazine section headings
sect2.para: Example:

sect2.title: Techniques
sect2.para: This is newly-introduced markup to support the techniques ontology, and is currently used in Nature Protocols and Nature Structural & Molecular Biology.
Set <subj-group> with @subj-group-type="technique". Each technique should be set in a separate <subject> with @content-type="npg.technique".
Use <named-content> for each part of the ontology:

listitem.para: content-type="code" for the technique code number
content-type="version" for the ontology version number, currently 1.7.0
content-type="id" for the technique id number
content-type="path" for the full path of the technique number

sect2.para: Example:

sect1.title: Article information
sect1.para: Most article information should be tagged in <article-meta>. Information on the publishing stage and original source status should be set in <custom-meta-group>.

sect1.title: Article title
sect1.para: See related element: <title-group>
The main article title should be marked up as <article-title>. Do not use @id.
Do not include emphasis that encompasses an entire title.

sect2.title: Hidden title
sect2.para: Where there is an instruction to not show an article title, wrap title text in <styled-content> with @style-type="hidden".

sect2.title: Short title
sect2.para: An article will sometimes also have a short title. This should be marked as <alt-title> with @alt-title-type="short-title".

sect2.title: Subtitle
sect2.para: Tag only the content of the subtitle in the <subtitle> tag. @content-type should not be used.

sect2.title: Topics
sect2.para: An authored "pretitle" should be marked up as <subtitle> with @content-type="topic".

sect2.title: Alternative article title
sect2.para: Science-Business eXchange may have an alternative article title for the HTML version only. Mark this up using <alt-title> with @alt-title-type="alt-title", e.g.
sect2.programlisting: <title-group> <article-title>REThinking lung cancer</article-title> <alt-title alt-title-type="alt-title">Targeting RET in lung cancer</alt-title> </title-group>

sect2.title: Footnotes on the title
sect2.para: If there is a footnote to the title, put the <xref> (with @ref-type="fn") in the <article-title> or <subtitle> element, and set the <fn> in the <fn-group> (with @content-type="footnotes") in <back>.

sect1.title: Article types
sect1.para: The "article-type" attribute is required on <article>. See <article> for details on tagging the attribute. The article type should be provided by the Nature editor, e.g. "cstory" for a cover story. Journals use a range of article types and therefore it is not possible to provide an exhaustive list here.
[* Include notes on different article types *]

sect2.title: Nature jobs (@article-type="naturejobs")
sect2.para: These articles may contain one or more Nature codes representing career stage, discipline and sector. These should be set in a separate <subj-group> for each type with @subj-group-type taking the respective values "career", "discipline" and "sector". They should contain a <subject> element for each code.

These articles may also contain one or more Nature codes representing regional information. Each region should be set in separate <subj-group> elements with @subj-group-type="region". This element should always contain a <subject> element with @content-type="continent". It may also contain child <subject> elements with @content-type="country", "state" and "area".
Example:
sect2.programlisting: <article-categories> <subj-group subj-group-type="career"> <subject>nj_c1</subject> </subj-group> <subj-group subj-group-type="discipline"> <subject>nj_d2</subject> <subject>nj_d10</subject> </subj-group> <subj-group subj-group-type="region"> <subject content-type="continent">na</subject> <subject content-type="country">USA</subject> <subject content-type="state">MA</subject> <subject content-type="area">Boston</subject> </subj-group> <subj-group subj-group-type="sector"> <subject>nj_s1</subject> </subj-group>

sect1.title: Author information
sect1.para: Author information should be set in the following order for Nature articles:

listitem.para:
<contrib-group> containing a separate <contrib> for each author:
<name> — required for Nature articles
possible <role> element
possible <bio> element
possible <xref> links to affilation (@ref-type="aff"), correspondence info (@ref-type="corresp"), author footnotes (@ref-type="author-notes") and/or author declarations (@ref-type="statement")
each <contrib> should have @contrib-type set to "author" or "editor"
each <contrib> should have @corresp set to "yes" if correspondence information is given, or "no" when it is not
<aff> — each affiliation contained in a separate <aff> tag with address elements used where possible
<author-notes> —

sect1.para: Set any label or symbol in the <label> element. Do not create symbols or labels in the XML if they do not exist in the published article. Follow copy for all punctuation.
Example:
sect1.programlisting:
Scott Cameron C Verheije Monique H * Pelkmans Lucas Titus Sandra Biochemistry Department, University of Geneva, Geneva, Switzerland Virology Division, Department of Infectious Diseases and Immunology, Utrecht University, Utrecht, The Netherlands Tel.:+41 44 635 31 23; Fax:+41 44 63 56 830; lucas.pelkmans@imls.uzh.ch

for Sandra Titus: The views expressed are those of the author and do not reflect the official position of the Office of Research Integrity, Department of Health and Human Services, or any component thereof.

Present address: Pathology Division, Department of Pathobiology, Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Utrecht University, Yalelaan 1, 3584 CL, Utrecht, The Netherlands

sect2.title: Collaborative authors
sect2.para: Use <collab> when a group of authors is credited under a single name.
Example:
[*Add example from ng2127 once transforms will convert the whole thing*]

sect2.title: Contributors
sect2.para: Where articles have contributors rather than authors, for example in interviews, use <contrib-group> with @content-type="contributor".
<contrib> should have @contrib-type set to "interviewee" or "interviewer".
Affiliations should be included in the <contrib>.
Example:
sect2.programlisting:
Heber Joerg Joerg Heber is a Senior Editor at Nature Materials. Ramshaw Ian

is a professor and group leader of the Vaccine Immunology Group at the John Curtin School of Medical Research (JCSMR) at the Australian National University (ANU). Ian is Director of the National Centre for Biosecurity, which was established at the ANU in 2006 to facilitate greater academic engagement with biosecurity.

sect1.title: Copyright Information
sect1.para: Tag all copyright information within <permissions>.
Tag the copyright year (usually the current year) in <copyright-year> whether or not it appears as part of the <copyright-statement>.

Tag the copyright holder in <copyright-holder>. This will be "Nature Publishing Group" for the majority of our journals. Scientific American and Scientific American Mind should use "Scientific American, Inc.".
<copyright-statement> will vary between journals and should reflect the copyright line used in the pdf version of the article. Emphasised text should not be used.
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <permissions> <copyright-statement>© 2012 Macmillan Publishers Limited. All rights reserved.</copyright-statement> <copyright-year>2012</copyright-year> <copyright-holder>Nature Publishing Group</copyright-holder> </permissions>

sect1.title: Dates
sect1.para: Within metadata, there are two date elements, <date> and <pub-date>. Tag publication dates (issue date, aop etc) in <pub-date> and history dates (received, accepted etc) in <date> inside <history>. The date model is the same for both. It allows parsed date information (<day>, <month>, <season>, <year>).
Do not use 00 or empty elements if values for day, month or year are not known/given.
Tag <day>, <month>, and <year> as integers - two digits for day and month (01-12 and 01-31), four digits for years. Do not use <season> for Nature articles.
See <history> and <pub-date> for additional information.
For examples of using dates inside citations, see References [*add link to ref section*].

sect1.title: DOCTYPE declaration
sect1.para: The root element is <article>.
Set the PUBLIC identifier to "-//NLM//DTD Journal Publishing with OASIS Tables v3.0 20080202//EN".
Set the SYSTEM identifier to "journalpub-oasis3.dtd".
sect1.programlisting: <!DOCTYPE article PUBLIC "-//NLM//DTD Journal Publishing with OASIS Tables v3.0 20080202//EN" "journalpub-oasis3.dtd">

sect1.title: Footnotes
sect1.para: Tag author footnotes in <author-notes>. See Author information.
Tag footnotes that apply to the article as a whole in <fn-group> in <back>.
Information concerning grants, contracts, sponsors, or other funding for the research should be captured in <funding-group>.
Tag table footnotes in <table-wrap-foot>.
See also <fn>.

sect1.title: Interviews and quizzes
sect1.para: Use <list> with @list-content set as "interview" or "quiz". Do not use @list-type or @id.
Each block of a question and answer is contained in a <list-item>.
Each question and answer will be a sub-list with @list-content set as "question" or "answer".
Example - Interview:
sect1.programlisting:
If you could list only five markers or transcription factors that people who study skin stem cells really need to know, what would they be?

Key factors for the hair follicle stem cells are Sox9, Tcf3, K15, CD34 and Lgr5. Key markers that encompass epidermal and hair follicle stem cells are p63, K14 and K5, but these proteins are expressed by all keratinocytes with proliferative capacity, irrespective of whether they are stem cells or transit amplifying cells.

One thing you've done a lot of is marking and following cells. How do you decide what labels to use?

There is no crystal ball as to how to accomplish this, as you always run the risk of altering the biology of the protein. You just have to do the controls to test for preservation of protein function. Let me offer a few examples:

If we just want to look at Sox9 expression, but only in cells that express Sox9, then we would engineer the Sox9 locus to express GFP [green fluorescent protein] under the control of the Sox9 promoter, so that GFP expression will be exclusive to the cells that express endogenous Sox9. Here it would be important to use a short-lived GFP, such that the minute the cell switches off endogenous Sox9 expression, you'll lose GFP protein.
sect1.para: Example - Quiz:
sect1.programlisting:
This apparatus, held in London's Science Museum, has some significant purpose — or curiosity value — in the history of physics. Can you guess what it is?

Last month: Caroline Herschel's telescope

This reflecting telescope was built in about 1795 by Sir William Herschel, who gave it to his sister Caroline. A dedicated assistant to her brother, Caroline was a celebrated astronomer in her own right, discovering eight comets and three nebulae. She described vividly the experience of astronomical observing on "star-lit nights on a grass-plot covered with dew or hoar frost, without a human being near enough to be within call".

Caroline Herschel described the telescope pictured here as looking exactly like the one used by her brother in the discovery of Uranus. It has a 7-foot octagonal wooden tube and is operated using pulley ropes and gears. The 6-1/8-inch mirror is made of speculum metal, an alloy of copper and tin.

sect1.title: Journal information
sect1.para: Set complete journal information for each article in <journal-meta>.

sect1.title: Link Groups
sect1.para: Link Groups to related job adverts and websites should be modelled as <ref-list> with @content-type="link-group within <back>. Set each link within <element-citation>.
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <ref-list content-type="link-group"> <title>DATABASES</title> <ref-list> <title>OMIM</title> <ref> <element-citation><ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/dispomim.cgi?id=104300">Alzheimer</ext-link> </element-citation> </ref> <ref> <element-citation><ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/dispomim.cgi?id=143100">Huntington</ext-link> </element-citation> </ref> </ref-list> </ref-list> <ref-list content-type="link-group"> <title>linkout</title> <ref> <element-citation><ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://www.ibecbarcelona.eu/">IBEC (Institute for Bioengineering of Catalonia)</ext-link></element-citation> </ref> <ref> <element-citation><ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://www.upf.edu/en/">Pompeu Fabra University</ext-link></element-citation> </ref> </ref-list>
sect1.para: See also <element-citation> and <ext-link>.

sect1.title: Materials and Procedures (Nature Protocols)
sect1.para: Nature Protocols contains Materials and Procedures sections which should be modelled using <sec> with @sec-type="materials" or "procedures" and <title> taking the value "Materials" or "Procedures". Do not use @specific-use for these sections.
Subsections of materials and procedures should be modelled using <list>. @id is unnecessary for these lists.
These sections may also contain "caution", "critical", "timing" and "trouble" statements. They should be modelled in the following way:

listitem.para:
caution — as

with @content-type="caution" within the relevant
critical — as a sub-list with @list-content="critical"

timing — as

with @content-type="timing" for the first timing statement. Nested timing statements should be contained in the same

and wrapped in the element also with @content-type="timing", e.g.
listitem.programlisting: Protein expression Step 1: 2 h Step 2: 16 h (S)-4-hydroxy-2-keto-4-(2′-pyridyl)butyrate synthesis Steps 3–4: 8 h Step 5: 24 h

listitem.para: trouble — as a sub-list with @list-content="trouble". If the "trouble" statement contains "problem" and "solution" sub-statements set these as further sub-lists with @list-content="problem" or "solution", e.g.
listitem.programlisting:
Low cell yields for the various cell preparations due to inadvertent loss during centrifugation steps for reasons such as choosing an inappropriate centrifugation speed or discarding wanted fractions.

When performing procedures for the first time, examine aliquots of all fractions under the microscope to become familiar with the expected cell morphologies. At various stages during the preparation, compare cell morphologies to those of the final preparations shown in the top row panels of Figures 2 and 3.

sect2.title: Materials
sect2.para: For materials sections, use a <list> for each "Reagents" and "Equipment" section and set sub-lists for all sub-sections with titles. All lists and sub-lists should have @list-type="materials".
Example:
sect2.programlisting:
Materials Reagents

Mice, neonatal or adult in the resting phase (telogen) of hair growth; athymic nude mice

All procedures involving live rodents must conform to National and Institutional regulations.

Troubleshooting advice can be found in Table 2.

Cells (freshly isolated primary keratinocytes and Fbs)

 Equipment

Sterile 50-ml tubes

Cell strainer 100 µm (BD Falcon)

Sterile Stender dish, small beaker or crystallizing dish

Sterile funnel

 Reagent setup Calcium chloride

Prepare 0.25–0.3 M stock solution, filter sterilize, determine actual calcium concentration by atomic absorption.

 DNASE

Prepare 20,000 U ml−1 solution in PBS, sterilize with low protein binding 0.2-µm filter; store frozen in small aliquots.

 Collagenase

Prepare 0.35% (wt/vol) in Fb culture medium, agitate on rocker for 10 min, centrifuge at 2,800g r.p.m. for 10 min, filter sterilize through low protein-binding filters, first through 0.45 µm with prefilter and then through a 0.2-µm filter; store at 4 °C.

sect2.title: Procedures
sect2.para: For procedures sections, use <list> for each main section and set sub-lists for all sub-sections with titles. All lists and sub-lists should have @list-content="procedure-group".
Each step of a procedure should be set as a sub-list with @list-content="step". Steps may be nested.
Where a "pause" statement appears, this should be set as a sub-list with @list-content="pause".
Example:
sect2.programlisting:
Procedure Synthesis of 2,2-dithioethyl-4-(2′-pyridyl)-4-butyro-γ-lactone

Dissolve 400 mg of (S)-4-hydroxy-2-keto-4-(2′-pyridyl)butyrate in 6 ml of ethanethiol and 2 ml of concentrated HCl. Stir the mixture for 24 h at room temperature.

Ethanethiol has a strong stench and is a skin irritant. Concentrated hydrochloric acid will cause skin burns.

Reaction can be left stirring overnight.

Remove excess ethanethiol by distillation.

Extract the resulting solid three times with 10 ml of methylene chloride. Combine the organic extracts, wash with water and dry the organic phase over MgSO4. The organic extracts are then concentrated, leaving a yellow oil.

The product is analyzed by chiral gas chromatography using a chiral Chromopack Chirasil-L-Val column (25 × 0.25 m) at a temperature of 160 °C and a pressure of 15 psi to determine the enantioselectivity. A racemic product was synthesized as a calibration standard (Box 1).

Troubleshooting advice can be found in Table 1.

sect1.title: References
sect1.para: A reference list (<ref-list>) is a series of references (<ref>). Generally each reference item contains only one citation element. For Nature articles, use <mixed-citation> for all references, but see Link Groups for an exception.
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <ref-list> <title>ORIGINAL RESEARCH PAPERS</title> <ref id="b1"> <mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><string-name><surname>Kohrt</surname>, <given-names>H. E.</given-names></string-name> <etal/>. <article-title>Stimulation of natural killer cells with a CD137-specific antibody enhances trastuzumab efficacy in xenotransplant models of breast cancer</article-title>. <source>J. Clin. Invest.</source> <year>2012</year> <month>02</month> <day>13</day> (doi: <elocation-id content-type="doi">10.1172/JCI61226</elocation-id>)</mixed-citation> </ref> </ref-list> <ref-list> <title>FURTHER READING</title> <ref id="b2"> <mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><string-name><surname>Vanneman</surname>, <given-names>M.</given-names></string-name> & <string-name><surname>Dranoff</surname>, <given-names>G.</given-names></string-name> <article-title>Combining immunotherapy and targeted therapies in cancer treatment</article-title>. <source>Nature Rev. Cancer</source> <volume>12</volume>, <fpage>237</fpage>-<lpage>251</lpage> <elocation-id content-type="doi"> 10.1038/nrc3237</elocation-id> (<year>2011</year>)</mixed-citation> </ref> <ref id="b3"> <mixed-citation publisher-type="book">“<source>Sources of Nitrogen Compounds in the United States</source>.” By <string-name><prefix>Dr.</prefix> <given-names>C. G.</given-names> <surname>Gilbert</surname></string-name>. (Smithsonian Institution, Washington, <year>1916</year>.)</mixed-citation> </ref> </ref-list>
sect1.para: See also <element-citation>, <ref-list> and <ref>.

sect1.title: Sections/Subsections
sect1.para: Sections and subsections are identifiable by their titles. If an article does not have a titled opening section, do not set one in the XML.
All sections must contain <title>. Do not use <label> in Nature articles.

Subsections should be nested. However, to mirror Nature's current practice, also set @specific-use as "heading-level-#", where # shows the level of nesting. [Once we are publishing directly from NLM, we can deprecate this requirement.]
Example:
sect1.programlisting:
With the ever-increasing importance of clinical effectiveness and audit, the only way of ensuring the proper undertaking of evidence-based research on a large scale is to standardize methods of measurement.

Aim

To examine the relationship between ICON and the subjective opinions of patients attending for routine dental care.

 Objectives

To calibrate examiners to an acceptable level of reliability.

To determine the subjective opinions of 11–14 and 30–40 year olds with respect to aesthetics, function, speech and treatment need.

 ...
sect1.para: See also Materials and Procedures, where <sec> is used to model alternative section types.

chapter.title: Elements
chapter.para: These XML elements have specific style rules associated with them. This is not a complete list of XML elements included in the NLM Journal Publishing DTD. For guidance using elements not listed here, consult the NLM Tag Library.

sect1.para: Articles may contain more than one abstract. Specify the attribute @abstract-type for summaries which are not true abstracts.
Capture only the abstract in this tag. Other metadata like copyright information, citation information, and keywords are not part of the abstract.
Do not use <label> or <sec> elements in Nature content.

listitem.para: @abstract-type not stated – use only for a true abstract
@abstract-type="first-paragraph" – Where the first paragraph of an article is used as an abstract, it should be set as an abstract in <front> and not as a paragraph in <body>

@abstract-type="web-summary" – A "web summary" is an article summary, usually an abridged version of the first paragraph, restricted to online delivery. This type of abstract may also contain a child

to show location, see example below

@abstract-type="toc" – Another type of "web summary" which is restricted to the table of contents for online delivery. This type of abstract may also contain a child

to show location

@abstract-type="editor" – An "editorial summary" is an article summary restricted to online delivery and is only displayed on the editorial summary page with the associated article(s), and does not appear on the full text article. The @specific-use should also be stated, with possible values of "aop" or "issue". This type of abstract may also contain a child <title> element.
@abstract-type="synopsis" – A "synopsis" is an article overview, not a true abstract, restricted to online delivery and is not displayed on the full text article.
@abstract-type="standfirst" – A "standfirst" is an article summary, not a true abstract, that appears both in print and online.
@abstract-type="executive-summary" – An "executive summary" is an article summary, not a true abstract, restricted to online delivery and used for the Nature Reviews series.

@abstract-type="key-points" – A "highlights" section is a list of article highlights, restricted to online delivery and is only displayed with the synopsis, and does not appear on the full text article

sect1.para: Example showing an article with multiple abstracts:
sect1.programlisting:
Microorganisms

It is now accepted that microorganisms primarily control iron redox chemistry in most environments. Under anoxic conditions, Fe(III) oxide minerals are reduced by Fe(III)-reducing microorganisms (FRM). The ubiquity of FRM and their phylogenetic diversity makes this microbial metabolism globally significant. FRM can use both organic (CO2) and inorganic (H2) electron donors.

—The Editors

Washington

Anaerobic microbial iron oxidation and reduction contributes significantly to soil and sediment biogeochemistry and mineralogy in anaerobic environments. Here, Weber and colleagues review the diversity of microorganisms involved in these processes, and the unique biochemical challenges associated with utilizing an insoluble metal substrate.

Iron (Fe) has long been a recognized physiological requirement for life, yet for many microorganisms that persist in water, soils and sediments, its role extends well beyond that of a nutritional necessity.
sect1.para: attributes:

listitem.para: abstract-type — see examples above
id — not required for Nature articles
specific use — only required when @abstract-type="editor" and takes the value "aop" or "issue"
xml:lang — not required for Nature articles

sect1.para:
The article acknowledgements, where they exist, should be set as multiple

elements in one element.
Within <ack>, do not use <label>, <title>, <sec> or <ref-list> in Nature articles.
Attributes are also unnecessary on <ack>.
The root element for all Nature articles.
The "article-type" attribute is required, e.g. @article-type="cstory".
attributes:

listitem.para: article-type — (#REQUIRED)
xml:lang — "en" is the default and does not need to be explicitly stated; use "de" for German and "ja" for Japanese (Kanji)
xmlns:mml — Fixed value "http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"
xmlns:oasis — Fixed value "http://docs.oasis-open.org/ns/oasis-exchange/table"
xmlns:xlink — Fixed value "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"

sect1.para: This is a required element that holds subject and other "sorting" type information about the article.
[*Add more detail*]

sect2.title: Series title
sect2.para: Non-subject-based collections of similar articles across multiple issues of a journal should be set as <series-title> with @code declared. Currently, this only applies to EMBO Reports and Scientific American.
Example:
sect2.programlisting: <article-categories> <subj-group subj-group-type="category"> <subject>ss</subject> </subj-group> <series-title content-type="food_science">Science & Society Series on Food and Science</series-title> </article-categories>

sect1.para: Articles should have at least two article-id elements, containing the unique identifiers assigned to the article. The two expected article-id attribute values are @pub-id-type="doi" and @pub-id-type="publisher-id".
@pub-id-type="guid" and @pub-id-type="alt-doi" may also be included.
Tag only one identifier per <article-id> element.
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <article-id pub-id-type="doi">10.1038/scibx.2010.940</article-id> <article-id pub-id-type="publisher-id">scibx.2010.940</article-id>
sect1.para: attributes:

listitem.para: pub-id-type — (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: Tag all article metadata for each article. All articles must contain <article-id>, <article-categories>, <title-group>, <pub-date> and <permissions> (see Copyright Information).
Article metadata may also contain <contrib-group>, <volume>, <issue>, <fpage>, <lpage>, <history>, <related-article>, <abstract> and <kwd-group>.
<custom-meta-group> may also be used for corrections and retractions.

The article back contains information that is published with the article but outside of its main narrative flow. Set reference lists, acknowledgments, appendices, author information, and article-level footnotes in the back matter.
See <ack>, <app-group>, <bio>, <fn-group>, <glossary>, <ref-list> and <notes>.
Within <back>, do not use <title>, <label> or <sec> in Nature articles.

Author information, where it exists, should be set as multiple

elements in one element.

Within , do not use any children apart from

for Nature articles.
Attributes should also not be used on <bio>.

Carries all of the article body. It allows

and all block-level objects and then repeating recursive sections ().
Use <title> for section titles. Do not just set the section titles in <bold> or other formatting.
Back matter elements, such as <app-group>, <glossary> and <ref-list>, should not appear at the end of <body>.
All figures and tables should be collected in <floats-group> after <back>.
Where values for <fpage> and <lpage> have been included in the article metadata, set the total number of pages in <counts><page-count> with @count equal to the number of pages.
Do not use any other children of <counts>: equation-count, fig-count, ref-count, table-count or word-count.
Used for capturing article/journal metadata which does not have a specific tag.

listitem.para: Publication stage — set <meta-name> as "publish-type"; <meta-value> has possible values: "supp", "aop", "online", "nfv", "prototype", "offline", "retired" and "issue". However, "issue" is the default value and does not need to be explicitly stated.
Original source — if the article is taken from another journal, set <meta-name> as "original-source" and <meta-value> as "no".

sect1.para: Example:
sect1.programlisting: <custom-meta-group> <custom-meta> <meta-name>publish-type</meta-name> <meta-value>aop</meta-value> </custom-meta> <custom-meta> <meta-name>original-source</meta-name> <meta-value>no</meta-value> </custom-meta> </custom-meta-group>

sect1.para: Page identifier for an article that does not have traditional page numbers. Currently, this should only be used in Bonekey and Scientific Reports.
Can contain an email address or the name of a person or organisation. @xlink:href should show the email address.
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <email xlink:href="jiangyan03@263.net">jiangyan03@263.net</email> <email xlink:href="sarah_glenister@scientist.com">Dr Sarah Glenister</email>

sect1.para: Used to tag link information to objects outside of the article. The text may be a repeat of the content in the @xlink:href or it may be different.
attributes:

listitem.para: @ext-link-type — set as "uri" for a link to a website (starting with "http:" or "/"); "ftp" for a link to an ftp site [*plus any additional possibilities*] (#REQUIRED)
xlink:href — Holds an identifier of or locator to an object available through or at that resource. (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: See also Accession Groups and Link Groups.
Do not use
attributes:

listitem.para: fn-type — only required when <fn> is used to model objects which are not article footnotes, e.g. "other" for endnotes
id — only required when <fn> is used for article or table footnotes

sect1.para: Do not use <label> or title for footnote groups in Nature articles.
The first page of the article. See also <lpage> and <counts>.
Carries all of the article front matter. It allows <journal-meta>, <article-meta>, and <notes>.
<journal-meta> and <article-meta> are required.
Do not use <notes> in the front matter. [* Any instances where we do want this? *]
Do not use <glossary> in Nature articles.

This element is used to contain one or more historical dates relevant to the article. Each <date> must have a @date-type. Articles cannot have more than one <date> with the same @date-type. Tag only one date per <date> element.
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <history> <date date-type="created"> <month>09</month> <year>2008</year> </date> <date date-type="received"> <day>12</day> <month>11</month> <year>2008</year> </date> <date date-type="rev-recd"> <day>24</day> <month>12</month> <year>2008</year> </date> <date date-type="accepted"> <day>17</day> <month>02</month> <year>2009</year> </date> </history>
sect1.para: attributes:

listitem.para: date-type — Set as "created", "received", "rev-recd" (revision received), "accepted" or "misc" [*additional info on when "misc" should be used*]. (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: Contains the ISSN(s) for the journal. Articles must have at least one <issn>. If a journal has more than one ISSN, include in successive <issn> tags.
attributes:

listitem.para: pub-type — Set as "ppub" for a print ISSN and "epub" for an electronic ISSN. (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: See <journal-meta> for an example of markup.
Set issue numbers as an integer only. Do not include the word "issue" or any related abbreviation in the element.
If there is no issue number (for example, in an AOP article), do not insert an empty element.

This element usually takes the value of an abbreviated form of the journal title, e.g. scibx for Science-Business eXchange, nneuro for Nature Neuroscience. A full list can be found in the Journal-specific information chapter.
attributes:

listitem.para: journal-id-type — Set as "publisher". (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: See <journal-meta> for an example of markup.
Contains all information about the journal.
Requires <issn>, <journal-id>, <journal-title-group>, and <publisher>.
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <journal-meta> <journal-id journal-id-type="publisher">scibx</journal-id> <journal-title-group> <journal-title>Science-Business eXchange</journal-title> </journal-title-group> <issn pub-type="epub">1945-3477</issn> <publisher> <publisher-name>Nature Publishing Group</publisher-name> </publisher> </journal-meta>

sect1.para: The complete title of the journal in which the article is published should be contained in the child <journal-title> element. Do not use <abbrev-journal-title>, <journal-subtitle> or <trans-title-group>.
[* Are there any exceptions where we would want to use these tags? *]
See <journal-meta> for an example of markup.
Set each keyword in kwd. Do not use <label>, <title> or <compound-kwd> in Nature articles.
Where a glossary id is given for a particular keyword, set this as <named-content> with @content-type="glossid" and @specific-use set as the value of the id.
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <kwd-group kwd-group-type="author-generated"> <kwd>atypical presentation</kwd> <kwd>renal medullary carcinoma</kwd> <kwd><named-content content-type="glossid" specific-use="ncp_2292"/>sickle-cell disease</kwd> </kwd-group>
sect1.para: attributes:

listitem.para: kwd-group-type — Set as "author-generated" for keywords created by the author, otherwise do not use.

sect1.para: Contains licence information for the article and is contained in <permissions>.
Atttributes:

listitem.para: license-type — formed by the permissions model ("by-nc-nd" or "by-nc-sa"), followed by a dash, and the version number
xlink:title — the name of the licence
xlink:href — the url of the licence explanation page

sect1.para: Child <license-p> elements contain any explanatory text and also <funding-source> with @source-type set as "author-paid" or "author-not-paid".
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <permissions> <copyright-year>2010</copyright-year> <copyright-holder>Nature Publishing Group</copyright-holder> <license license-type="by-nc-sa-3.0" xlink:title="Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-Share Alike 3.0 Licence" xlink:href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/"> <license-p>This is an open-access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution Noncommercial Share Alike 3.0 Unported License, which allows readers to alter, transform, or build upon the article and then distribute the resulting work under the same or similar license to this one. The work must be attributed back to the original author and commercial use is not permitted without specific permission.</license-p> <license-p><funding-source source-type="author-paid"/></license-p> </license> </permissions>

sect1.para: A regular <list> should not have a <title> in Nature articles. It must have one <list-item> for each point in the list.

Do not use as a block-level element in Nature articles, it should always be contained within

or .
<list> may also be used to model other article objects. See also Interviews and quizzes and Materials and procedures.
attributes:

listitem.para: id — (#REQUIRED)
list-type — Allowed values: "bullet", "number", "ucletter", "lcletter", "lcroman" and "ucroman". "bullet" is the default value, but should still be declared for regular lists. (#REQUIRED)
prefix-word — This is for a word that should prefix the generated label in the list, eg. "Step". Do not use for Nature articles.

sect1.para:
Contains exacty one item per tag. Each item may contain multiple

or other block-level elements.
Do not use <label>.
The last page of the article. Include the value even if it is the same as the first page. See also <fpage> and <counts>.
Maintain all punctuation from the original copy.
Should be used for citations within text and for bibliographic references.
Example - inline:
sect1.programlisting: Federico Peña, the DOE secretary, sacked AUI in May after an internal report criticized management and environmental procedures at the laboratory (see Nature 387, 114; 1997).
sect1.para: Example - bibliographic reference:
Insert example here
See also References and <element-citation>.
Paragraph. Contains text of article.
@content-type should only be stated when modelling the following objects:

listitem.para: @content-type="cross-head" — Heading text which does not define a section of text
@content-type="dateline" — City or country where article originates
@content-type="greeting" — Line at top of letter containing greeting, e.g. "Sir,"
@content-type="caution" — Procedural caution note (only found in Nature Protocols)
@content-type="timing" — Step timing (only found in Nature Protocols)

sect1.para: Do not use @id or @specific-use.

Used to contain publication dates relevant to the article. Each <pub-date> must have a @pub-type. Articles cannot have more than one <pub-date> with the same @pub-type. Tag only one publication date per <pub-date> element.
Example:
sect1.programlisting: <pub-date pub-type="issue-date"> <day>01</day> <month>05</month> <year>2009</year> </pub-date> <pub-date pub-type="aop"> <day>22</day> <month>03</month> <year>2009</year> </pub-date>
sect1.para: attributes:

listitem.para: pub-type — Set as "issue-date" (date of publication of print issue), "aop" (advanced online publication), "collection" [*equivalent of "iss" in Nature - find out what that means*], "epub" (online only journals), "epreprint" or "embargo" [*additional info on those*]. (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: Requires <publisher-name>. This should be the same text as used in <copyright-holder>. Refer to Copyright information.
Do not use <publisher-loc>.
See <journal-meta> for an example of markup.
Links to related articles [*lots of possible link types - give full explanation when all have been covered*]
attributes:
Defines the subjects of an article within <article-categories>. These are often used to indicate the Table of Contents headings for an article.
Do not include any <xref> links within <subject>. Any article-level footnotes that must be referenced should be referenced from the <article-title>.
This holds the <article-title>.
It may also contain <subtitle>, <alt-title>. Do not use <fn-group> or <trans-title-group>.
If the article is a book review, see <article-title> for special rules. [*This text is from PubMed guidelines. Check Nature practice and add information if necessary*]
Set volume numbers as an integer only. Do not include the word "volume" or any related abbreviation in the element.
If there is no volume number (for example, in an AOP article), do insert an empty element.
Used to reference objects within the article. Do not include emphasis or punctuation within the element.
@rid may contain multiple id values.
Do not wrap <xref> in <sup>, Nature CSS stylesheets will handle this.

table.title: Required values for @ref-type [verify against Nature practice - I don't think we assign ids to a lot of these elements]

sect1.para: [*Different to NPG practice*] Tag ranges of cross references by including an <xref> for the first item, an en-dash (–), and an <xref> for the last item.
The changes in education level demonstrate the changing attitudes. 1–3
The changes in education level demonstrate the changing attitudes.1–3
<xref> may be empty or contain text. For example,
sect1.programlisting: In the presented 3D ground-plane cloak, we choose the parameter distribution in the x–z plane as that for the 2D cloak given in ref. 18. Then, we get the full 3D parameter distributions by rotating it around the z axis. Comparing with the original designs, the 2D ground-plane cloak described in reference Ma et al. has a much smaller size (about four times smaller).
sect1.para: attributes:

listitem.para: ref-type — This is the @id of the referenced object. (#REQUIRED)
rid — see the table above for allowed values and ID/IDREF prefixes. (#REQUIRED)
id — Do not use.

chapter.title: Journal-specific information
chapter.para: [*Add information for particular journals, e.g. journal-id, copyright-statement, etc*. Delete information for defunct/irrelevant products.]

row.entry: Journal of Cerebral Blood Flow & Metabolism
Journal of Database Marketing and Customer Strategy Management
Journal of Derivatives and Hedge Funds
Journal of Direct, Data and Digital Marketing Practice
Journal of Exposure Science and Environmental Epidemiology
j expo sci environ epidiemiol jesee
Journal of International Relations and Development
Journal of Investigative Dermatlogy Symposium Proceedings
j investig dermatol symp proc jid symposium proceeding
Journal of Retail and Leisure Property
Journal of Targeting, Measuremenat and Analysis for Marketing
Journal of the Operational Research Society
nat struct mol biol nsmb nsmba
nat struct mol biol nsb nsmba
Protein Structure Initiative Structural Genomics Knowledgebase
